save.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to make someone or something safe from danger, harm, or destruction
save.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Emergency aid could save millions threatened with starvation.
a new treatment that could save his life
She was determined to save her marriage.
the campaign to save the rain forests
He saved the child from drowning.
save.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to keep money in a bank so that you can use it later, especially when you gradually add more money over a period of time
save.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He managed to save enough to buy a small house.
I’m saving up for a new car.
save.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to use less money, time, energy etc so that you do not waste any
save.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: We’ll save a lot of time if we go by car.
Everyone is being encouraged to save energy.
ways to save money on heating bills
save.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to keep something so that you can use or enjoy it in the future
save.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: We’ll save the rest of the food and have it later.
I had a bottle of champagne which I’d been saving for a special occasion.
save.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to keep all the objects of a particular kind that you can find, so that you can use them
save.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: I’m saving up vouchers to get a cheap air ticket to the States.
save.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to help someone by making it unnecessary for them to do something that they do not want to do
save.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: If you lent me £5, it would save me a trip to the bank.
I’ll get a taxi from the station to save you the trouble of coming to collect me.
save somebody the trouble/bother (of doing something)
I’ll take the shopping home in the car to save you carrying it.
save.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to stop people from using something so that it is available for someone else
save.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Will you save me a seat?
We’ll save some dinner for you if you’re late.
save.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to make a computer keep the work that you have done on it
save.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Don’t forget to save before you close the file.
Did you save the changes that you made?
save.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to stop the other team from scoring in a game such as football
save.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: The goalkeeper just managed to save the shot.
save.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: in the Christian church, to free someone from the power of evil and bring them into the Christian religion
save.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to gradually collect money by not spending all the money you have, especially when you regularly put some of it in a bank
She doesn’t earn much, but she still manages to save a few dollars each week.
We’re saving for a deposit to buy a house.
to regularly save part of the money you earn, especially over a long period of time
You should start setting aside part of your earnings as retirement savings.
to try to save money by spending less on the things you need and by saving what you can, especially when you do not earn very much
My parents scrimped and saved for years to send me to college.
to keep something, especially money, in a safe place to be used later
I wanted to surprise her, so I squirreled away a couple of dollars a week to spend on a present.
to spend less money by buying only the things that you really need, or by buying cheaper things
Weddings can be expensive, but you can economize by doing some things yourself.
save.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an action in which a player in a game such as football prevents the other team from scoring
save.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Martin made a brilliant save from Nichol’s shot.
save.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: She answered all the questions save one.
